Easily. Truth is a word. Like any symbol in any logic that word can itself have a truth value, and that value may be false. This paradigm of perspective whereby one object has multiple representations such that none of those representations characterise the object completely is one of the pillars of postmodernism. The now-infamous quote is itself completely dependent upon punctuation: “ ‘truth’ isn’t truth” means something quite different to “truth isn’t truth”.  It depends on your orientation. You may need screen lock to stop your device pandering to your perspective. Context is everything - that’s what quotation marks are all about - they denote attribution. ‘Truth’ isn’t truth because attribution of the quality ‘truth’ is not identical to the quantifying value ‘truth’ as it is used in a logical truth-table.  Therefore, we can imagine a scenario whereby p or q is named ‘truth’. An example might be ‘I told the truth’. However, immediately, we see that this is not necessarily valid because of the presence of self-referentiality - truth is being told by the teller. How do we know the teller is telling the truth when the truth is what the teller tells? This is how truth can not be truth. Because ‘truth’ may be indistinguishable from the teller, depending on the tell that the audience takes to be truthful. Rhetoric is magic. Only some know the tricks of the trade. The point is always ‘how you’re looking determines what you see’. People can be made to do that…using only mere punctuation sometimes. Spelling it out is no fun. The fact is that information has always been a battlefield. My advice is to pay attention to silence. The real action is usually taking place where the words are not. Ignore the big loud guy - he’s the misdirection. Trust me.

Ok, whatever is actually true IS the truth. Though it is possible to tell something that is not what happened without it being a lie. IF a person sees an event from a different place it is possible that they might draw an incorrect conclusion. They believe their conclusion to be the truth and will tell it. This isn’t a lie it is simply a mistake. They might also believe a story told to them by someone because they trust that person, if that story is wrong but they repeat it they will think they are telling the truth. It isn’t the truth they were deceived. A LOT of that about at the moment.
